intro: Anacampseros ruschii, commonly known as the ghost plant, is a succulent species native to southern Africa. It belongs to the family Aizoaceae, which includes many other flowering plants adapted to arid environments. The plant is characterized by its fleshy, water-storing leaves that are often covered in a fine layer of white powder, known as farina. It produces small, star-shaped flowers in shades of yellow, orange, and red during the warmer months. Due to its unique appearance and drought tolerance, it is a popular choice for rock gardens and xeriscaping.
